Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to investigate distributed algorithms for online optimization over networked multi-agent systems. Online optimization refers to the best use of limited agent resources in scenarios where information is dynamic, not a priori available, and increasingly revealed over time. An underlying assumption of present online optimization approaches is the availability of information at a central location. This assumption becomes problematic in networked scenarios, where information is distributed among agents. Transmitting all data to a central location might be costly or inefficient, and raises privacy concerns and the possibility of information leakage. The research will result in the design of robust, distributed strategies that can deal with multiple sources of disruption present in real-world applications. The research approach progresses from the synthesis of online distributed algorithms via saddle-point dynamics to the development of rigorous mathematical analysis with provably correct guarantees. Deliverables include a catalog of provably correct online distributed strategies, novel concepts and tools for the evaluation of performance and complexity, demonstration and validation via computer simulations, documentation of research results, and engineering student education.

Networked robotic systems have an enormous impact in a wide range of modern applications, including oceanographic exploration, disaster recovery, environmental monitoring, and surveillance. The current trend in scientific and military domains points towards the deployment of these systems in uncertain scenarios where communication is limited and subject to failure and interference. A successful outcome of this research will enable the robust and efficient operation of networked systems in these highly decentralized scenarios. The research will be broadly disseminated and positively impact a variety of educational activities, including high-school, undergraduate, and graduate education, involvement of undergraduates in research, supervision of graduate students, and retention of minorities in STEM disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Networked interconnected systems are extending the range of human capabilities in an increasing number of scenarios, ranging from the power and transportation grids to multi-robot systems in search and rescue and disaster response operations. The current trend in scientific and military domains points towards the deployment of such networked systems in uncertain scenarios where information is dynamic, not a priori available, and increasingly revealed over time. Given the limited resources available to the network, such scenarios bring to the forefront the need for optimizing the operation of the individuals. The premise of this project was the combination of the strengths of online and distributed optimization in the design of efficient, robust computational techniques for solving such network problems. An underlying assumption of current online optimization approaches is the availability of information at a central location. This assumption becomes problematic in networked scenarios, where information is distributed among agents. Transmitting all data to a central location might be costly or inefficient, and raises privacy concerns and the possibility of information leakage. All these considerations motivate the focus on distributed methods that do not rely on this "centrality of information" assumption.

On the intellectual merit side, project outcomes include the development of understanding of the network structure and mechanisms that enable a teams of agents to operate in a robust and resilient fashion and the design of a suite of coordination strategies to achieve this. Specifically, the policies developed under this project (i) have sublinear regret bounds in time that guarantee optimal asymptotic performance with respect to the best decision in hindsight, i.e., had all the information been centrally available a priori, (ii) are feedback mechanisms that fuse the fragmented information available across individuals, incorporate it on the fly, and are distributed and scalable, enjoying fast convergence guarantees; and (iii) can handle multiple sources of disruption present in real-world applications, such as noise and delays, link failures and dynamic interaction topologies.

On the broader impacts side, the research of this project has contributed to the theoretical foundations needed to enable the robust and efficient operation of networked systems in a wide range of applications with societal impact.  The research has made an impact in the training of a new generation of scientists and engineers at UC San Diego, from incoming undergraduate students all the way to the postdoctoral scholar level, who have developed the skills necessary to deal with the type of multi­faceted systems and applications considered in the project. Specific outcomes include mentoring and supervision of undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral students, lab tours and outreach activities to incoming freshman, transfer, high school, and middle school students to provide motivation to engage in STEM disciplines and retention of minorities.  The results have been disseminated through conference and journal publications, online availability of preprints and publications, invited research talks delivered at top institutions, invited plenary talks at conferences and other professional research meetings, various roles in workshop and conference organization, hardware demonstrations at robotic forums and workshops, instruction at summer schools, and organization of special issues in archival publications.
